results.content:
Clear, concise, and covers the most important frameworks. The exercises were fine, but my preference would have been for more short exercises spread throughout rather than just three exercises (one for each framework).

The opinions that Maximilian provides seem well reasoned, and definitely are of value to anyone struggling to choose a framework. His analysis near the end of the course seemed sound, and was well worth the patience of working through the introductions to each framework.

A worthwhile course for anyone about to undertake a large Javascript project.

results.content:
Maximilian Schwarzmüller definitely knows what he is talking about, as far as I can tell. He seems to have lots of experience and is able to transport his knowledge and insights to the viewer. The concept of the course itself, introducing each framework briefly with the same tasks before comparing them all together, is didactically clever. I had a lot of fun watching the the videos and could comprehend almost any example and explanation.

However, at some (rare) points I found his speed of writing code a bit too fast. I think its because of his profound knowledge, that he simply isn't aware how others may have a hard time following him at this pace... But then, I just skipped back and watched the critical section once again to get it.

In conclusion, this was my first but definitely not last Udemy course of him. Whether we go for Angular or Vue JS, I'll be back. :-)

Asks you to solve the same problem with each of the frameworks (and then shows you his solution each time) so that you can experience the similarities and differences between them.
Finishes up with some comparison lectures, explaining when you might want to use each framework in your own professional life.
An excellent introduction to these popular JavaScript frameworks.

results.content:
Every course I've purchased from Max (maybe 6 at this point) is head and shoulders above and beyond other courses purchased from nearly any other source.  

Max, your service to the world in sharing your knowledge in an extremely organized manner is truly a gift to all those working to learn programming. 

This is an important course and series of topics for those about to spend 1-2 years working to become proficient in either Vue, React, or Angular.  I think many devs are coming at these JS frameworks with minimal exposure, meaning with bkg in PHP or JAVA but not necessarily the front end MVVC space.  

It's a big decision, and if you're juggling a day job, you've got hundreds of hours of training and practice ahead of you.  The fear is of course that you'd make the wrong choice.  

As Max identifies in the course, there are significant pros and cons to each framework.  I think he does an excellent job of fairly defining parameters for each.  

So, highly recommended course, especially for those for whom VueJs is where you are spending your time.  This will give new and intermediate VueJs devs a stronger foundation.

I would like to mention that there may be licensing and/or legal concerns in some areas for both Angular and React, more so for React.  At least one primary dev for a major framework has expressed concern (see Oslo talk on comparison of 6 JS frameworks, last few minutes of hour lecture) over license restrictions if your app may future-compete in Facebook's sandbox.  For me, I needed completely clean licensing; so, Vue was my choice, assuming that the contributor marketplace would catch up and that Vue would eventually take on both React and Angular.

Max, thanks for another great course.

results.content:
If like me you come from a Web development background, but are heavily on the back end and need to move around a bit (usually employability reasons!) then you might be scratching your head a bit wondering what about Angular, Vue and React?  What are they and why should I bother aside from the job market?

This course does exactly that: it really answered all my questions and gives a decent comparison and quick overview of each.  (It does need an update here, the vue-cli package for example has moved on and you will need to consult the docs).

All I wanted to know was what's all the fuss about with these frameworks, which one, and why, and a little of each so I could help my decision making, like which one I find enjoyable to use and where can I apply this knowledge for my needs (e.g. for mobile)?

This course does a spectacular job of answering all those questions before you waste a lot of time and money trying each one and getting to a decent level of proficiency before you realise you might have wanted one or the other instead.

results.content:
The course is beginner friendly. It only assumes that you know JavaScript. It gives enough explanation of everything else, so you can know the reason and differences between different frameworks. It gives enough context to be able to compare them intelligently. It explains why things the way they are, so you can see advantages/disadvantages of each framework.
It might goes too deep and spends over hour and a half for each framework, but it might be good to see if you would like that type of development or not.

results.content:
This is the first time I've ever given a course 5 stars.

Max really knows what NOT to teach in an "intro" video to make each of these frameworks seem very approachable. I feel a lot more comfortable talking about these frameworks, understanding the paradigms behind each of them, and I feel primed to go into a course on any one of these frameworks without being confused.

Before taking this course, I took Wes Bos' "React for Beginners" course and my head was spinning because of the pace. This was perfect - probably gonna take Max's React course rather than going back to Wes'.

results.content:
I think the videos are too small (1-2 minutes), specially if you're following the course on a brief period of time. In every video there's the 'flashback' (what you've learned on the past video) and there are a lot of videos with chit-chat (like "on the next video we'll see how you can xxxxx") or videos that mostly repeat what has been said before, which are, in my opinion, a waste of time. It would be better if this type of introduction is present on the specific video instead of having two different videos.

Besides this, I think the core concepts of each framework should be present on a specific module (that is, components, directives, and so on). Key concepts don't play any role in this course, things just get introduced as you go along.

results.content:
This course did exactly what the title says.

After the course I had a clear view about what each framework/library did and how I could use it in my personal projects but also how it would hold together in bigger projects or company projects.

And as always every course no matter how good has a few negative points.

1. The github stars example in the end is nice but it also changes rapidly and thus not a really reliable source. Pointing us to look at the github ourselves to check the populairity would have been better.
2. Also the amount of jobs is nice but I think just pointing out that we should look on indeed if we want to know the job availability would have been a better thing to do.
3. At the somewhat more difficult concepts I find the pace too fast. But on the other hand the easier to understand concepts are in my opinion a little too slow.

Taking everything into account it is a fantastic course and definetly worth buying altough I would recommend to buy it with a coupon code.

results.content: Max is excellent at building online courses, and is a fantastic presenter. Rather than bogging down too much into the technical benefits or faults of each framework, he focuses on what its going to be like to work in each framework on a day to day basis. Even if you have already decided on a framework, this course has value in showing you competing opinions of what modern web development should entail. Would be outstanding if it included Aurelia as a fourth framework - but that is a more than reasonable omission.

results.content: A well structured course that delivers exactly what its title suggests. If you're coming from a basis of some understanding of or at least exposure to "vanilla" JavaScript (ES5), and want to know what the Angular, React, and Vue frameworks are all about - and particularly how to decide between them - this course is a great place to start. The exercises are simple enough for those with little JavaScript experience and yet use enough features to provide a valuable introduction to the frameworks and the subtle and not so subtle differences between them.
results.content_html: A well structured course that delivers exactly what its title suggests. If you're coming from a basis of some understanding of or at least exposure to "vanilla" JavaScript (ES5), and want to know what the Angular, React, and Vue frameworks are all about - and particularly how to decide between them - this course is a great place to start. The exercises are simple enough for those with little JavaScript experience and yet use enough features to provide a valuable introduction to the frameworks and the subtle and not so subtle differences between them.

results.content: The content and flow was thoughtfully structured to explain how and why certain constructs and concepts are to be what they are, often showing certain things do not work as one may expect. This was refreshing and more effective to retain the knowledge because it gives deeper understanding of the topic than simply glancing over the surface matters. The delivery was excellent and engaging. He was fair to all competing frameworks, libraries, and infrastructure tools. One thing I felt was missing was the angle from more on computer science and historic perspective such as the trendy adoption of purer functional programming in many disciplines including UI landscape. In this regard React is spearheading with all others following or mimicking at least. I think this is a significant milestone opening up a new vista of programming which may well be the future (Angular and Vue seem to be in the same old school in this regard).

Maximillian is a great teacher who is able to convey ideas concisely and in an easily understandable way.

results.content: Very informative course by an excellent instructor. The individual modules that implement the same tasks in Vue, Angular and React are great as a "getting started" tutorial for each framework, as well as providing a good basis for comparison. The extended summary in the final module looks at many other important aspects besides code, such as performance and job prospects. The only thing missing for me was a deeper look into the history, philosophy and design patterns of each of the frameworks.
